text: We'll hear argument now in Number 96-1768, C. Elvin Feltner v. Columbia Pictures Television.
Thank you, Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court--
The concept of statutory damages has changed some, has it not, from 1856 to 1909?
Certainly--
The guidelines, or whatever you want to call it.
--Yes.
I take it in the '56 act there was no opportunity to elect a different damage scheme after verdict but before a judgment as there is in the current act.
That's right.

So if we followed your reasoning in this case, as I think your opponents have pointed out, we would have to accept as a consequence that a jury could render its verdict on actual damages, be discharged, go home, and at that point the election could be made to go for statutory damages, and I don't know what happens then.
That's a false problem.
But it could happen, couldn't it?
--I don't think so.
Mr. Chief Justice, may it please the Court--
Did the Tull footnote 7 in effect say that's not a consideration that should influence--
No, it didn't.

--Mr. Tashman, if I follow your argument correctly, then if a copyright holder comes in at the outset and says, I want the court to find that there has been an infringement and I want statutory damages, I don't want any other kind of damages, could such a plaintiff then avoid having a jury trial on the question of infringement?
Absolutely.
There seems to be a debate about what... the number of infringements, whether that was, in fact, a summary judgment--
--Oh, there's no question about it.
--But whether each episode counts as a work.
Correct.
Mr. Roberts said that is a mixed question of law and fact.
It is, except in this case there was no dispute as to the facts, and we don't dispute the facts.

Well, I don't want to distract you with a question that would be peculiar just to this case, but I think you have made an important clarification that in your argument statutory damages are just like injunctive relief, so if you come into the court and say, all I want is an injunction, then the infringement will be determined by the court as well.
Yes, I think that would flow once the court, or if the court characterized the statutory damages as an equitable remedy and an equitable--
Why didn't the--
--Well, there's a huge amount of discretion involved.
Thank you, Mr. Chief Justice.
They returned general verdicts where there was a statutory specified amount for each sheet?
Sure.
But I mean, it wasn't a great mystery what the calculation ought to be.
No.
So we'd have to overrule Tull, in your view.
--No.
Thank you, Mr. Roberts.
